In addition to giving descriptions of the various battles within the war and the associated Clan Jade Falcon invasion, it provides details of all th eunits involved and rules on running games and campaigns set within this period.
93097.name: Classic BattleTech: FedCom Civil War

93098.name: Aquaquest
93098.description:
Aquaquest is situated in an imaginary world with a central mountain and six countries. Each player is leader of one of the countries. Each country has a large lake, two rivers that are shared with other countries and a sea.

There are two kinds of water tokens in the game: blue for clean water and brown for dirty water. The goal of each player is to get the water situation in the country right, which means there is no dirty water in the country and there are exactly six clean water tokens in the lake.

Water flows from the mountain to the sea. Also hovering clouds evaporate water or rain down water on the land, depending on weather conditions.

The game has three levels, increasing in complexity but also making the game less random.

rpgitemversion: Base set of 80 Cards Plus Promos
93100.name: Shadow over Nentir Vale (Fortune Cards)
rpgissuearticle: Dungeons & Dragons: Fortune Cards — Shadow Over Nentir Vale
93100.description:
User Summary:

Shadow Over Nentir Vale is the first set of 80 themed "booster" cards released by Wizards of the Coast for their Dungeons & Dragons 4e game (specifically designed for use with the D&D Essentials brand). The set of 80 cards are themed to fit into the setting material being released for 2011 (the newest D&D Encounters Season: The March of the Phantom Brigade and the upcoming Monster Vault: Threats to the Nentir Vale). The cards come in packs of 8 with one rare card (a small star appears on the bottom to indicate rare card). The cards come in three varieties: Attack, Defense and Tactic. A user-made deck needs to be somewhat balanced between these three types of cards.

From the Publisher

Dungeons & Dragons Fortune Cards, sold in booster packs of 8 cards, give players fun new ways to survive the challenges of the D&D Encounters in-store play program, as well as their home campaigns. These cards give characters fun, temporary benefits that feel different from the benefits gained from powers and feats, without adding undue complexity to the D&D game.

How to Play

At the start of each encounter, shuffle your deck and draw a card.

You can play one card per round. It requires no action to play. The rules on each card state when you can play it and what effect it has. A card takes effect just once unless it states otherwise, and you discard the card when its effect ends.

You can have only one Fortune Card in your hand at a time. At the start of each of your turns, you can do one of the following:

* Discard the card in your hand and draw a new one.
* Draw a new card if you don’t have one in your hand.
* Keep the card that’s in your hand if you haven’t played it.

93101.description:
From the back of the book:

Aerospace assets bridge the gulf between the stars in the thirty-first century, making interstellar travel, and interstellar war, possible. WarShips escort JumpShips as they tear a hole in the fabric of the universe to jump thirty-light years towards a distant star; DropShips detach and make the million kilometer trip to the destination planet; aerospace fighters protect the DropShips burning into the destination's atmosphere, as the defender's aerospace fighters rise to meet them -- all to land a MechWarrior and his precious 'Mech on the field of battle.

AeroTech 2: Record Sheets is an all inclusive book that contains a filled-out record sheet for every conventional fighter, aerospace fighter, small craft, DropShip, JumpShip, WarShip and Space Station, along with all variants, currently in use with in the BattleTech universe. In all, this book contains 319 filled-out record sheets, providing a single book for the complete aerospace assets of the BattleTech universe.

User comment:

This behemoth of a book contained printed new record sheets for every aerospace and naval asset in the BattleTech/AeroTech/BattleSpace universe at the time of printing. It's not surprising that an expansion this large also had an errate published for it, the year after printing.

This record sheet set is listed as out of print by the current licence holder, and no electronic version is available. With some items from this era being re-printed, it may be that an electronic version could be available in the future.
93101.name: BattleTech: AeroTech 2 Record Sheets

93102.name: Demonsblood (Issue 3 - Jul 1979)
93102.description:
User Summary:

Cover art by Simon Robins.

Demonsblood was published as a combination of contributor "minizines" and regular articles. Minizines are indicated with an asterisk in the contents list below.

Page 2: Contribution/Subscription details
Page 3: Bestial Growls (editorial) - Brian Dolton
Page 4: The Mysteries of Mentyrr (PBM D&D) - Colin Ingham
Page 6: Werewolf Comments 2 1/2* - Brian Dolton
Page 7: The Killing of Thomas Clib (story) - David Jones
Page 11: The Raven Croaks* - Andy Ravenscroft
Page 15: Quaestor* - Andrew Key
Page 18: Chronicle of Kawar* - Kevin Reader
Page 23: Ichor Transfusion 1* - J.L.T. Patterson
Page 28: Reviews (The Apprentice, Alpha Omega) - Paul Blackwell
Page 29: Things That Go Bump In The Night (new D&D monsters)
Page 31: Character File (new D&D NPC's) - John Norris

93103.description:
From the back of the book:

For five long years the Inner Sphere has know war on a scale not seen in centuries, with the militaries of literally every faction involved in combat to one extent or another. Now, as relative peace appears to be settling over the Inner Sphere, a review of the military forces of the BattleTech universe are in order.

Classic BattleTech Field Manual: Updates updates all ten Field Manuals, including a history section that will bridge the gap between where the appropriate Field Manual left off and the current year of 3067, as well as a complete and current TO&E for all factions. Updated random 'Mech assignment tables for all factions are also included.

User comment:

This sourcebook updates all of the ten volumes released by FASA as the Field Manual series, moving the timeline in each up to early 3067. While it doesn't add any new rules, units or equipment to those revealed in the Field Manual series, it does update the unit locations and the tables used for generating different force elements, which is very useful for generating games or campaigns.
93103.name: Classic BattleTech Field Manual: Updates

93104.name: Six Superb Mounts
93104.description:
Publisher Blurb

Don't just ride around on a boring horse. Grab one of the mounts in Escape Velocity Gaming's newest supplement - "Six Superb Mounts". Each mount is fully illustrated with a new, original drawing. Each has the full 4e stat block and a first-person narrative-style description. Enjoy the bonus tokens that you can print and cut out for table-top play!

93106.name: ZauberZeit (Issue 18 - Aug 1989)
93106.description:
(user summary)

table of content:

News
Kim Stanley Robinson - portrait
book reviews
game reviews

Schwarzwald Requiem - CoC scenario, part 1
Schwertverschwörung - scenario idea for Midgard
Von Scharlatanen, Sängern und Spionen - scenario idea for MERP
Die Diener des Roten Königs - alchemy in RPGs

Kriegfried & Lavendell - comic

93107.name: ZauberZeit (Issue 19 - Oct 1989)
93107.description:
(user summary)
table of content:

News
Knochenhaus - short story
Stephen King special
book reviews
game reviews

Schwarzwald Requiem - CoC scenario part 2
Die hohe Kunst, den Drachen zu reiten - 3 unusual mounts

Kriegfried & Lavendell - comic

93108.name: Warrior, Rogue & Mage Draft
93108.description:
From Introduction:

WR&M is a simple, lightweight roleplaying game that allows a group of players and a gamemaster to experience epic adventures in a fantasy world filled with wondrous magic. This booklet assumes you are familiar to RPGs. If you have no idea how a RPG is supposed to work, ask your geek friends, they'll know.

93109.name: Golden Tee Fore! 2004
93109.description:
User Summary

Golden Tee Fore! 2004 is the 13th version of the long running Golden Tee series. It offers seven new courses to play. Kings Canyon, Blue Stone, Heartland Creek, Eagles Peak, Tropical Falls, Blue Horizon and Swords Pointe.

The game follows the normal rules for golf play. All scoring is done for stroke play (hazards, water penalties etc.) You are provided with a standard set of clubs. 2-9 irons, 3 and 5 woods and a driver. Sand and pitch wedge and a putter.

Prior to the swing you can turn left or right. By rolling the roller ball (controller) back in a certain direction (for backswing) then foward in a certain direction, you can accomplish different shots including slices, hooks, fades and knock down shots. There is also a backspin button to allow backspin on the green.

The game also keeps track of high scores for each course including:
-the thirty best scores -Great golfer points (scored by getting shots within 5' of the hole from at least 50 yards out)
-longest drive
-longest putt
-fewest putts
-most greens hit
-most fairways hit
-most birdies
-most eagles or better

Golden Tee Fore! has additional features such as player identification, statistics tracking and online tournaments. Player identification is enabled through the use of the Golden Tee Card. Players can use this card to keep track of stats and play in on-line tournaments.

93110.description:
From the CH webpage:

WHITE BEACH ONE: Peleliu 1944 is just for you if you are ready to smash your way ashore at the infamous island, as one of the soldiers of the 1st Marine Regiment under Marine nonpariel Chesty Puller. It's for you if you are ready for a colorful map, new die-cut counters depicting weapons like the T20 shoulder-fired mortar. If you want historical leader counters, a battlfield unlike any other in the annals of historical modules. Taut scenarios, easily digest special rules in two column format.

"Ten hut!" It's time to get in the boats... then back out of the boats and ashore. You'll be wading in all the way as the water is shallow and inside the reef at Peleliu's White Beach One. And once you go ashore we're planning one way for you to come back out, and that' with a captured enemy battle flag clutched in your fist, the job done and done well.

Now for the real deal. WHITE BEACH ONE: Peleliu 1944 is a new historical module that provides 8 scenarios, all playable on the new map and ranging from fast-play to monster. It includes a sheet of new color die-cut counters and special rules pages in two column format. If you've been following the HBO miniseries 'The Pacific" or perhaps read "With the Old Breed" a few times (we know you have) then you're already equipped with the intel that these here are Chesty Puller's Marines and you are ready for this experience NOW!


THIS IS NOT A COMPLETE GAME. STATUS MARKERS, RULEBOOK, AND PLAY AIDS ARE NEEDED FROM ANY COMPLETE GAME.

All Japanese and Marine unit counters are included.
93110.name: ATS: White Beach One – The Marine Landing on Peleliu 1944

93111.name: Golden Tee Fore! 2004 Extra
93111.description:
User Summary

Golden Tee Fore! 2004 Extra is the 14th version of the long running Golden Tee series. It offers the seven courses of Fore 2004, plus two additional courses new courses to play. Kings Canyon, Blue Stone, Heartland Creek, Eagles Peak, Tropical Falls, Blue Horizon, Swords Pointe, Cedar Meadows and Shadow Swamp.

The game follows the normal rules for golf play. All scoring is done for stroke play (hazards, water penalties etc.) You are provided with a standard set of clubs. 2-9 irons, 3 and 5 woods and a driver. Sand and pitch wedge and a putter.

Prior to the swing you can turn left or right. By rolling the roller ball (controller) back in a certain direction (for backswing) then foward in a certain direction, you can accomplish different shots including slices, hooks, fades and knock down shots. There is also a backspin button to allow backspin on the green.

The game also keeps track of high scores for each course including:
-the thirty best scores -Great golfer points (scored by getting shots within 5' of the hole from at least 50 yards out)
-longest drive
-longest putt
-fewest putts
-most greens hit
-most fairways hit
-most birdies
-most eagles or better

Golden Tee Fore! has additional features such as player identification, statistics tracking and online tournaments. Player identification is enabled through the use of the Golden Tee Card. Players can use this card to keep track of stats and play in on-line tournaments.

93112.name: Golden Tee Fore! 2005
93112.description:
User Summary

Golden Tee 98 is the 15th version of the long running Golden Tee series. It offers seven new courses to play. Blue Horizon, Eagles Peak, Ridgewood, Painted Gorge, Oak Hollow, Sapphire Springs and Balmoral Greens

The game follows the normal rules for golf play. All scoring is done for stroke play (hazards, water penalties etc.) You are provided with a standard set of clubs. 2-9 irons, 3 and 5 woods and a driver. Sand and pitch wedge and a putter.

Prior to the swing you can turn left or right. By rolling the roller ball (controller) back in a certain direction (for backswing) then foward in a certain direction, you can accomplish different shots including slices, hooks, fades and knock down shots. There is also a backspin button to allow backspin on the green.

The game also keeps track of high scores for each course including:

-longest drive
-longest putt
-fewest putts
-most greens hit
-most fairways hit
-most birdies
-most eagles or better

Golden Tee Fore! has additional features such as player identification, statistics tracking and online tournaments. Player identification is enabled through the use of the Golden Tee Card. Players can use this card to keep track of stats and play in on-line tournaments.

93113.name: Golden Tee Live
93113.description:
User Summary

Golden Tee Live is the 16th version of the long running Golden Tee series. It offers new courses to play.

The game follows the normal rules for golf play. All scoring is done for stroke play (hazards, water penalties etc.) You are provided with a standard set of clubs. 2-9 irons, 3 and 5 woods and a driver. Sand and pitch wedge and a putter.

Prior to the swing you can turn left or right. By rolling the roller ball (controller) back in a certain direction (for backswing) then foward in a certain direction, you can accomplish different shots including slices, hooks, fades and knock down shots. There is also a backspin button to allow backspin on the green.

The game also keeps track of high scores for each course including:
-the thirty best scores -Great golfer points (scored by getting shots within 5' of the hole from at least 50 yards out)
-longest drive
-longest putt
-fewest putts
-most greens hit
-most fairways hit
-most birdies
-most eagles or better

93114.name: Golden Tee Fore! Complete
93114.description:
User Summary

Golden Tee Fore! Complete is the compilation version of the long running Golden Tee series. It offers a total of 29 courses to play.

The game follows the normal rules for golf play. All scoring is done for stroke play (hazards, water penalties etc.) You are provided with a standard set of clubs. 2-9 irons, 3 and 5 woods and a driver. Sand and pitch wedge and a putter.

Prior to the swing you can turn left or right. By rolling the roller ball (controller) back in a certain direction (for backswing) then foward in a certain direction, you can accomplish different shots including slices, hooks, fades and knock down shots. There is also a backspin button to allow backspin on the green.

The game also keeps track of high scores for each course including:
-the thirty best scores -Great golfer points (scored by getting shots within 5' of the hole from at least 50 yards out)
-longest drive
-longest putt
-fewest putts
-most greens hit
-most fairways hit
-most birdies
-most eagles or better

93117.name: ART 2.0 Tabletop Role-playing System
93117.description:
From publisher blurb:

ART is the tabletop role-playing system first popularized in Legendary Lives and later in Lost Souls. The ART system takes it name from the Action Results table, the mechanism used for all task resolution.

ART 2.0 builds on the innovations of the original ART system, creatng a system that is just as easy to use but even more flexible.

Author's Note
Through the years, the ART system has gone through several variations. The table even went away entirely in Khaotic and Crimes People Play. For ART 2.0, I wanted to return to the action results. I also wanted a system worthy of the "no calculator required" logo that was on the cover of the first edition of Legendary Lives.

To accomplish this, I've gotten rid of the roll required, column shifts, and couting columns. Instead of the narrator adjusting the roll for the difficulty, the difficulty is front loaded. A Great roll will now remain a Great result, and every action, no matter how difficulty, has the full range of 10 possible outcomes.

93125.name: Maelstrom Campaign Setting: Pantheon
93125.description:
From publisher blurb:

Unearth the powers that be in this first supplement sourcebook for the Maelstrom Fantasy Campaign Setting. This volume describes the world of Roil's pantheon and greater spirits, and is an invaluable resource for Game Masters and players alike.

Each deity is showcased on a separate page with their full-color symbol and complete information including alignment, domains, favored class and race, worshipper raiment and preferred armor and weapons, associated colors, holy days, sacrifice forms and times, the deity's role in the pantheon, the priests' roles, temple information, and other general information about the deity. Each spirit contains alignment, symbol, holy days, sacrifice times and forms, and associated colors information.

Contents include:

35 deities of the Roil Pantheon.
33 greater spirits of nature.
six new prayer domains.

93126.name: Maelstrom Campaign Setting: Worldbook
93126.description:
From publisher blurb:

Begin your journey and Unleash the Magic!
Enter an incredible world of harsh realities and wondrous magic. Roil is a world created and destroyed by the whim of the gods, and by the will of those who can command the Dark Furies.

Contents include:

Introduction into the world of Roil, its continents, its oceans and seas, its history, its inhabitants, its languages, and the dark furies, the Mists of Kaichea.
Five detailed perpetual calendars, complete with festivals.
Over 600 years of comprehensive history for the continent of Kaladia.
The Atlas of Kaladia: 23 Player maps showcase the continent of Kaladia, provided as highly detailed Indian-Ink style maps for easy viewing and printing.
52 nations of mankind on the continent of Kaladia, with detailed topics including demographics, cities and towns, terrain, climate, resources, languages, religion, government, and political state of affairs.
Seven humanoid domains of Kaladia.
Four barbarian lands of Kaladia.
Eight dominant currencies of Kaladia, including conversion rates, trade values, base metals and net weight.
Kaladia's great islands, independent cities, and destroyed realms.
An A to Z Glossary of Terms, including continents, oceans, seas, terrain features, nations, cities, deities, and other terms, used throughout the Maelstrom Campaigns.




Artwork:

World Map of Roil.
Continent Map of Kaladia
23 Highly detailed maps of Kaladia.
52 Heraldries: Each nation of mankind.

93127.name: Visira: City of Sorrows
rpgissuearticle: Review by GameWyrd: Visira: City of Sorrows by Darkfurries
93127.description:
From publisher blurb:

Visira. The City of Sorrows, in the dread realm of the Black Sword. Whose narrow streets echo tortured cries and the cruel whippings from taskmasters. Where the air is thick with the stench of blood and decay. It is a haven to the vile, the wicked, and the amoral. Where gold can buy anything, and life has the least value of all...

Visira is a powerfully detailed fantasy city sourcebook that is immediately usable in any campaign. While designed with unsavory elements, Visira is not a wholly evil city. Whether you're looking for a city to serve as your adventurers' headquarters, as your villain's base, or as the elaborate backdrop for countless adventures, Visira meets the challenge.

Contents include:

Over 100 detailed d20 System NPC residents.
26 aerial maps of Visira: 13 full color and 13 black & white designed for easy printing.
Seven intricately described city wards.
Arena's Hold - the warrior's realm of fighting pits, the gladiators' arena, and the corrupt gambling halls of the Black Thumb.
East Wash - Visira's oldest ward, in ruins from the floods of the Venom River.
Hillside - the tiered layers of the bluffs and the crust, dominated by Visira Keep and the citadel of Eteris.
Huckster Sprawl - a twisting maze where danger awaits the unwary, and the Rake terrorize with impunity.
Old Harbor - the ancient warf, torn and sinking, unchallenged domain of the lizardfolk Harvesters.
South Levee - filled with the bazaars of the Farmers' Market, and the garrison compounds of the Cannibals.
Waterfront - where pirates and merchants clash against the enigmatic Mariners Bevy, and the blue-skinned pleasure women of the Scarlet Veil capture the secrets of all.

The seven deities prominent within the city.
From the Trail of Tears, short stories recount tales of life in Visira:
An Unholy Land
Into Evil's Heart
The Price of Business
Broken Bones
The Hunting
The Reach of Revenge

93128.name: Leisure Suit Larry's Casino
93128.description:
Larry Laffer, the protagonist of the Leisure Suit Larry adventure series, is running a casino. Leisure Suit Larry's Casino offers 5 casino games, 3 party games, a full gift shop, 3 restaurants, 3 bars, and a few surprises. Also featured an online component which allowed for players to upgrade their hotel room, and participate in other online-only activities.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leisure_Suit_Larry,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93129.name: The Transformers Warrior Robot Game
93129.description:
A snakes-and-ladders-type game. Players each have two pieces and the aim of the game is be the first to get both pieces to the 'WIN' square. Players must decide which of their pieces to move on each turn.

Play starts on an outer track of the board and pieces transfer to the central track by landing on the relevant space. Players' pieces can be in vehicle mode (roll two dice to move) or robot mode (roll 1 die) and they transform between the two by landing on certain squares. Autobot symbols on the board act as 'ladders' allowing a piece to jump ahead and Decepticon symbols act as the 'snakes' causing a piece to move back to a previous square.

93130.name: Fragger
93130.description:
Throw grenades at your targets. Set the power of the throw and aim by moving the mouse. Click to throw the grenades and blow up your targets!

Source: The Game Website.

93131.name: Fragger Desert Strike
93131.description:
User Summary

A free (but separate) version of Fragger, the physics-based grenade-throwing game by Miniclip.

93132.name: Show Jumping
93132.description: A roll-and-move game from the 1960s. Players attempt to negotiate their horse-shaped playing pieces around the course collecting penalties and awards as they go. All faults are noted on the scoresheet and the player with the least faults wins. There is an advanced version which is against the clock.

93134.description:
Quick dice rolling game, using cartoon characters from the popular German artist Uli Stein. Each player represents one of the five cartoon animals.
The active player rolls six dice, then puts aside three, two or one die. This is repeated twice with the remaining dice. Each of his three rolls he must put aside a different number of dice. After the three rolls, the player representing the animal that is shown most on the six dice can check the other animals that were rolled on his/her scoring sheet. Whenever there are two policemen showing on the dice, however, nobody scores at all. When someone has checked an animal five times, s/he receives a victory point. The first player to collect two victory points is the winner.
93134.name: Einfach tierisch
boardgamepodcastepisode: Podcast #049 - Essen 2011 parte 2

93135.name: Malls & Morons Corebook
93135.description:
From publisher blurb:

Malls & Morons is a role playing game about teenagers in the mall, and the various misadventures they have as they avoid bullies, adults, and peer criticism in the eternal quest to gain coolness and influence among their peers. It is both a serious game and a comedy game, in that the rules themselves are not a farce and designed with a serious eye towards playability, while the game atmosphere and desired style of play is comedic. It is a light hearted game where the serious issues are ignored and the players will find themselves reveling in humorous antics of fights, breaking things, stealing things, insulting people, defying authority, and vandalism; plus other things we cannot and will not mention on a public site.

93136.name: The Druid
93136.description:
Publisher Blurb

In this offering you’ll find the druid profession tree. Druids are priests of the divinity found in nature, meaning that rather than worshipping a deity they place their faith in the raw power of the untamed wilderness, from its smallest plants to its largest beasts to the very land itself. By simultaneously controlling and petitioning the primal forces of nature, these priests of the wilds are able to wield its energies to perform miracles, usually in its defense.

93137.name: Sierra Vista Mall: A Setting for Malls & Morons
93137.description:
User summary:

All the information one would need to run players through the fictitious Sierra Vista Mall.

93138.description:
In Schlacht am Buffet, each player holds nine cards. In each turn, each player simultaneously selects a card and places it face-down on the table. Then the players take turns showing their card and moving their mice around the buffet table. After all cards have been revealed, the mouse which is alone in last place is eliminated and has to take the least valuable dish currently on the table. When all but two mice have been eliminated, the leading mouse gets the best dish (as long as it is alone on its field). The second placed mouse gets nothing. Afterwards, all players fill up their hands to nine cards.

Additional dishes of the same kind have to be stacked on previously earned ones. At the end of the game, only the top dish of each kind counts. When all dishes have been distributed, the game ends and the player with most points is the winner.
93138.name: Schlacht am Buffet
boardgamepodcastepisode: clp043 – cubelove podcast – Martin Wallace Short Review Smackdown

93139.name: The Champion
93139.description:
Publisher Blurb

In this offering you’ll find the champion profession tree. Champions are men and women imbued with holy power and set upon the path of fighting for their god’s will and goals. Not only can these warriors call upon their deity to grant them the power of miracles, but they can also channel this divinity in other ways that affect the world around them in very tangible ways, expressing their faith for one and all to witness.

93140.name: The Thief
93140.description:
Publisher Blurb

In this offering you’ll find the thief profession tree. At best, thieves tread within the grey areas of morality, using their rather specialized skills to take what they want from others. As such, they are masters of getting into places they don’t belong and (hopefully) getting back out with things that don’t belong to them. .

93141.name: Demonsblood (Issue 5 - Nov 1979)
93141.description:
User Summary:

Cover Art by Paul Blackwell.

Demonsblood was published as a combination of contributor "minizines" and regular articles. Minizines are indicated with an asterisk in the contents list below.

Page 2: Contribution and Subscription details
Page 3: Bestial Growls (editorial) - Brian Dolton
Page 4: GeordieCon Report - Brian Dolton
Page 5: Chronicle of Kawar Part 2* - Kevin Reader
Page 9: Tales of Tallraven 1* (includes D&D dungeon scenario)
- Dave Davies
Page 14: Return of the Psionic Ladybird* - Brian Asbury
Page 19: Heliosian Tales IV* - Dave Flin
Page 22: Werewolf Comments 4* - Brian Dolton
Page 26: The Routier's Tale* - David Jones
Page 28: The Raven Croaks 3* - Andy Ravenscroft
Page 32: Odd-Yetties 4* - Steve Barber
Page 34: Things That Go Bump In The Night (new D&D monsters)
Page 35: The Mysteries of Mentyrr* - Colin Ingham
Page 36: Character File (new D&D NPC's) - Simon Washbourne

93142.name: The Geomancer
93142.description:
Publisher Blurb

In this offering you’ll find the geomancer profession tree. Geomancers are skilled spell casters that utilize magic inherently tied to the earth, especially locations where magic or the like is strong. Also, by combining mathematical calculations and their knowledge of the earth’s ties to magic, a geomancer’s spells are much safer than is normal for most other Arcane Backgrounds.

Within this product you will find a new Arcane Background, Geomancy, as well as the Geomancer Professional Edge and 7 additional Professional Edges to round out its profession tree.

93143.name: Malls & Morons Additions
93143.description:
User summary:

New Feats, Classes and Prestige Classes for use in Malls & Morons.

93144.name: Demonsblood (Issue 6 - Jan 1980)
93144.description:
User Summary:

Cover Art by Oleg Zacharov.

Demonsblood was published as a combination of contributor "minizines" and regular articles. Minizines are indicated with an asterisk in the contents list below.

Page 2: Contents List/Contribution and Subscription details
Page 3: Bestial Growls (editorial) - Brian Dolton
Page 4: Odd-Butties 5* - Steve Barber
Page 8: Heliosian Tales 5* - Dave Flin
Page 10: The Acid Sorcerer Part 1 (AD&D magic items, and Angels)
- Graham Staplehurst
Page 15: Fat They Were And Furry Eyed* - Paul Blackwell
Page 18: Three Golden Apples II - Tom Keenes
Page 20: Werewolf Comments 5* (includes AD&D village scenario
and Superhero 44 scenario) - Brian Dolton
Page 30: Elemental Shamans (new AD&D class) - Brian Dolton
Page 32: The Creature That Ate Sheboygan (Review) - Andy
Ravenscroft
Page 33: An Atlas Of Fantasy (Review) - Andy Ravenscroft
Page 34: Things That Go Bump In The Night (new D&D monsters)
Page 32: Character File (new D&D NPC's) - Brian Asbury

93145.name: Legend Of Hero Tonma
93145.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Legend Of Hero Tonma", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Legend of Hero Tonma (レジェンド・オブ・ヒーロー・トンマ?) is a side scrolling platform game released by Irem to arcades in 1989.

The player controls a caped hero named Tommy in his quest to rescue a princess. Tommy can cast fireballs (which can be upgraded in power) to dispatch enemies, and jump on their heads to temporarily stun them.

93146.name: Breeder Compendium
93146.description:
From Back Cover:

A Wasteland guide screams in horror as he watches the 9mm rounds land with dull thuds upon the advancing Breeder - A Kyofu runs through a small nomadic encampment throwing people left and right as the beast corrals its victims - TAD officers continue to set up their temporary headquarters unaware that several cybernetically enhanced Breeders are on the hilltop scanning them with binoculars...

This is future Japan. A chaotic world where genetic tampering has created a race of creatures bent on the destruction of mankind. The Breeder Compendium is your guide to the chaos; an informative expose into the Breeder mindset.

Highlights include:

In-depth background (Project Dominion and Domination)
Reproduction
Expansion
Evolution and devolution
Wild Breeders
Breeder creation rules
Breeder examples
Akira-11 complex

93147.name: Last Resort
93147.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Last Resort (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Last Resort is an arcade shoot 'em up video game by SNK released in 1992. It was also released for the Neo-Geo and Neo Geo CD systems, as well as SNK Arcade Classics Vol. 1 for the PS2 and PSP. Extremely difficult, its gameplay was heavily inspired by R-Type and its system of pod attached to the player's ship. Its first level remained memorable for its homage to the futuristic Neo-Tokyo depicted in the anime Akira.

Taking place many years in the future, mankind has developed the technology for space colonization. However, a mysterious computer virus infects the primary computer running man's first space station, causing it not only to affect its automated defenses, but to convince other humans to side with it. The computer attacks Earth so often that Earth's only hope is put into advanced spaceships wielding great firepower.

The game uses only two buttons. The player maneuvers the cyber jet with the joystick. If the player has the drone it will rotate in the same direction of the cyber jet. Press the A button to fire bullets. If you have the drone it will fire in the direction it is pointing. Provided you have the drone, hold the A button to power up the gauge and let go to launch the drone in the direction it is pointing. The higher the power in the gauge the bigger the damage the drone can cause. Press the B button to toggle the stoptrack position of the drone, so it will stay on that point by the cyber jet, but the cannon on the drone can still rotate.

To obtain the drone, collect a power up. If the power up is blue, the attacks are electrical-based. If the power up is red, the attacks are fire-based. Different power ups grant different weapons to add to the cyber jet's attacks. The Laser is effective for shooting through enemies, the Missiles are suitable for spreadfire attacks and the Horizontal bombs are good for attacks either side. The weapons can be powered up to three levels on the cyber jet. Speed power ups can also be added to increase the cyber jet's speed. The cyber jet is destroyed by crashing into enemy ships or hazards or by being shot. The drone can block most bullets, but not lasers or large shots.

The game has five stages. In each stage, the player has battle through swarms of enemy war machines and planes. In some stages mid-bosses can be battled. If the player makes it far enough and the cyber jet is destroyed, the game can resume to a checkpoint, but cyber jet will lose all its power ups. When the player gets to the end of the stage, the player will have to battle a robotic boss, aiming fire on its weak point to destroy it.

93148.name: Demonsblood (Issue 7 - Mar 1980)
93148.description:
User Summary:

Cover Art by Simon Washbourne.

Demonsblood was published as a combination of contributor "minizines" and regular articles. Minizines are indicated with an asterisk in the contents list below.

Page 2: Who Is The Beast? - Brian Dolton
Page 3: Dead-Locks (letter column)
Page 5: Going Quietly Insane* - Paul Blackwell
Page 8: Moonsnake* - Steve Hawes
Page 11: The Raven Croaks 4* (includes Cerberus Class scoutship
for Traveller) - Andy Ravenscroft
Page 17: StabCon Report - David Flin
Page 18: Bestial Growls (editorial) - Brian Dolton
Page 19: Just A Series Of Events 1 (Superhero 44) - David Flin
Page 20: Odd-bunnies VI* - Steve Barber
Page 24: A dissertation from a dissertator (further editorial)
- Brian Dolton
Page 26: Tales of Tallraven II* - Dave Davies
Page 30: Heliosian Tales VI* - Dave Flin
Page 32: The Ways Of The Galaxy (new sci fi game) - Kevin Reader
Page 33: Character File (new D&D NPC's) - Simon Billeness
Page 34: There Shall Come A Wombat (Superhero 44) - David Row
Page 36: Contents List

93149.name: Burning Passion
93149.description:
Every one at some point or another has a little dispute with their partner, but few people feel the need to patch up their differences by duelling it across every room of the house.

Being a professional warrior has it perks but also its drawbacks. You may be the strongest around but you cannot handle losing even to your beloved one.

So beat them down and make them cry for mercy, then you can gloat and enjoy life, whilst they have to clean the house and pamper to your needs.

Burning Passion is a game for two players using a standard deck of cards and two simple character sheets. Each player has one character sheet and a selection of cards. Players simultaneously play cards into different rooms of the house trying to win the battle in each of the five rooms.

For every victory the player gains in a room they score one point. The first to ten points wins the game.

93150.name: Panzer Saint-Lo 1944
93150.description:
Panzer Saint-Lo 1944 invites you to command the axis and allies armies, in the mission to conquest the enemy’s command posts and obtain the victory.

As an allied general, you must recover the city of Saint-Lo and the surrounded area. But if you play as an axis general, your mission will be to resist and to defeat the allies, maintaining the control in the region.

Command the infantry, tank, artillery and aerial units that take part in the battle! Ask for reinforcements, avoid any danger with your supply units and take the necessary supplies that allow you to move and attack with you units. Only with tactic and strategy you shall get the victory!

Panzer Saint-Lo 1944 is a new, hex-and-counter board game, that simulates the battle of Saint-Lo, between german and American armies in July. 1944, during World War II. Each player had the control of half the board game, and have eight command post on towns, cities and strategic positions on it. The mission of each player is to move forward into enemy territory and destroy the enemy command post.

The game contains 210 counters, most of it whit a fine representation of guns and vehicles that took part in the real battle. Player have to command infantry, tanks, artillery, planes and supply units, in order to move into enemy terrain and to destroy enemy command post. The game involves use of resources as well, so movement and attack of units uses supplies counters, and players have to obtain supply every turn, through supply units.

Combat between units is defined with dices in a simple but smart way. Artillery units provide extra support to attacking units, obtaining powerful attack even with cheap vehicles.

The game also includes two card decks, one for each army. Cards provide extra power units and extra resources; it also makes shortage of ammo and fuel to the enemy.

As in the real battle, there is no invincible unit. Even if you play your Tiger I tanks or your B17 Flying Fortress bombers, you will need to beware of enemy infantry, light tanks or other enemy units. There are many ways to obtain victory, and to defeat the enemy, and only a good strategy is needed to gain the battle.

93151.name: Murder Mystery Party: Murder at the Grand
93151.description:
WHO MURDERED PROFESSOR EIN STEIN?

The time is 6th May 1944. The place is The Hotel Grand where a top secret conference has been arranged to reveal Professor Ein Stein's startling new invention- a deadly weapon. Professor Ein stein will not be attending the conference, he was found murdered in his room, apparently killed by his own invention. All of those attending the conference had high risk security clearance and could be trusted; But could they?

Join us in solving the Murder at The Grand.

The game box includes all the materials needed for the evening: menu and costume suggestions, the characters' booklets, party invites, name tags, etc.

93152.name: MLB 08: The Show
videogamehonor: 2009 D.I.C.E. Sports Game of the Year Nominee
93152.description:
MLB 08: The Show is a baseball simulation video game developed by SCE San Diego Studio published by Sony Computer Entertainment for the PlayStation 2, PlayStation 3, and PlayStation Portable systems. It the longest-running officially licensed Major League Baseball game series on the PlayStation systems.MLB 08: The Show is the third edition of the MLB: The Show series of video games. The game was announced for all three PlayStation consoles on December 11, 2007, and released on March 4, 2008 in North America. Ryan Howard, all-star first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, is featured as the game's cover athlete.

The game is a baseball simulation in which, depending on the gameplay mode, the player controls one or all of the players on a Major League Baseball team or some select Minor League Baseball teams. Depending on the gameplay mode, the player may control a team for a single game, season, or franchise, and can also create a player and control his career.

Source: Wikipedia, "MLB 08: The Show", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93153.name: Liquidation
93153.description:
Designer blurb:

Crossings is one of the biggest bookstore chains in the country. Due to a changing market and (according to some)
mismanagement, the company has been in pretty bad shape for a while. Now the other shoe has finally dropped,
and Crossings has declared bankruptcy. All of the stores are closing, just as soon as they can liquidate enough of
their merchandise. In the midst of it all, you’re going to become some of the employees and regulars, out to get the
best deals (or steals), settled grudges, or maybe just get your life in order before the inevitable end.

93154.name: White Collar
93154.description:
User Summary:

Traders and con-men spend other people's money on New York's Wall Street.

93155.name: Clangers
93155.description:
The box contains a number of parts that allow you to play one of two games; Tiny Clangers Party or Tunnels and Trees.

Tiny Clangers Party involves going around the board trying to visit 3 planets to collect 3 different presents and be the first to arrive at the Party in the middle of the board. Movement is by rolling dice, although you can collect and use pennies to add 1 to your move.

Flip the board over and you're ready to play Tunnels and Trees, which is just Snakes and Ladders in Space. Players roll dice to move along the board-track, with some spaces shuttling them ahead, and some sending them back to previous spaces. There's nothing original about Tunnels and Trees, but it does let you pretend that you're a Clanger inside their planet trying to get out.

93156.name: Kirby's Dream Course
93156.description:
Kirby's Dream Course (Kirby Bowl (カービィボウル Kābī Bōru) in Japan) is a 1994-96 golf video game developed by HAL Laboratory and published by Nintendo for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System video game console. It was first released in Japan on September 21, 1994, in North America on February 1, 1995, and in Europe on August 24, 1996. It is one of four Kirby video games released for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System. It was re-released to the Wii's Virtual Console in Japan, Europe and North America in 2007.

Gameplay

Dream Course is a golf video game which is viewed from an isometric perspective. Instead of a ball, the player tries to hit Kirby around the course and into the hole at the end. Players must set the power, angle, and spin to connect with various enemies found throughout the levels. Once only one enemy remains, that enemy will transform into the hole. The different abilities that Kirby can obtain from many of the enemies make up a large part of the game, often being required for completion of a hole. These abilities include Kirby turning into a tornado (that can be steered), a sparkly ball (that can destroy certain obstacles), and a UFO (which allows Kirby to float and move at will for a short time). Other abilities include Kirby being able to slow down / float with a parasol, as well as stop completely as a stone.

The game has eight single player courses, with eight holes on each. There is a high score board for each level, with medals to be won on each of them. The player can unlock extra features (such as alternative versions of the courses) by winning the medals. There are Bronze, Silver, and Gold medals to be won, which are awarded to Kirby at the end of the course. There are also four two-player courses (again with eight holes).
Kirby loses one of his health points (shown as tomatoes) every time he makes a shot, and gains one every time he hits an enemy or lands in a hole. In the two-player mode, two health points are awarded for landing in the hole first, and two health points can also be lost if one player's Kirby is "attacked" by the other player's by using an ability (such as the tornado or the stone). In the single-player mode, Kirby loses one life when all his health points are gone or fall off the stage ; when Kirby runs out of lives, the game will end. Afterwards, the player can either continue from the beginning of the course or exit it. In the two-player mode, the loss of all health points causes that player to miss a turn, as their Kirby falls asleep.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kirby's dream course", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93158.name: Dungeon Tiles: Rooms & Corridors Set #2
93158.description:
User Summary

The second dungeon tiles set includes several room & corridor tiles along with an underground river collection.

93159.name: Reggie Jackson Baseball
videogameversion: South America Sega Master System edition
93159.description:
User Summary

A Major League Baseball game for the Sega Master System. You can play as any of twenty six teams, for both American and National league. The interface allows you to select from among pitches, control your batting and even steal bases.
Try to win the series, a batting title or to win a two out of three tournament.

93160.name: Greeny Grasshopper's Card Game
93160.description: In turn, players spin the spinner and may discard one card from his hand if it matches an object that the spinner points to. Only one card may be discarded at a time even though a player may have duplicates. If a player's spin lands on a "Bug" space, and the player can discard "Greeny Grasshopper" from his hand, he may take another turn. Upon landing on the spaces marked "Take 1 or Take 2", the player must draw the amount of cards from the discard pile, unless there are no cards in the discard pile at this time. The first player to get ride of all his cards, wins the game.

93161.name: Swords & Sorcerers (First Edition)
93161.description:
User Summary

Swords & Sorcerers is a supplement for Chivalry & Sorcery and other generic role-playing games. The book discusses various cultures such as Vikings, Mongols, Celts, and Picts.

93162.name: Zaibatsu: Roleplaying the Corporate Wars of the Future
rpg: Zaibatsu: Roleplaying the Corporate Wars of the Future
93162.description:
from the introduction

Welcome to ZAIBATSU (pronounced "zEYE-bat-soo"). To play this game you need to get hold of a few friends, a couple of six-sided dice and an attitude. Finally you need to get a survival instinct. You won't be playing for long without one. Then again, ZAIBATSU is less of a game and more of a training manual for the urban nightmare that is near-future Tokyo.

Take Gibson's "Neuromancer" and related short stories; the visual kick of "Bladerunner", "Black Rain" and "Akira"; take the format and tangled firefights of Bullfrog's "Syndicate" game and splintered shards of Medieval Japan. The result is ZAIBATSU; roleplaying Japanese cyberpunk. Mean and moody manga. ZAIBATSU isn't watered down cyberpunk, near future elements from the best sources are here: replicants, lasers and cyborgs. All set in Gibson's futureworld: Tokyo gone global. Tokyo. The world's capital, largest, most high-tech, most happening city on Earth. Japanese culture is prevalent in many nations, just as American was in the 20th century. And the players are at the heart of this vast superpower. This is unique to ZAIBATSU, as is the world's retrogenics technology. Forget cybernetics in the traditional roleplaying game sense; with tech out of date as soon as it leaves the production line, no sucker is going to trade meat for metal if his new arm, say, will be redundant in two months. Now, updating the meat, that's something else... By the time we build a "stronger, faster" cybernetic arm or leg to replace the real limb, we will undoubtedly be able to regenerate a limb with clone technology. It's not too far away. The next step is to augment the DNA to grow a stronger limb, and after that use DNA viruses to alter existing limbs. Etc, etc.

Most of the rules in ZAIBATSU have been left to a minimum. Some may find this disturbing or annoying, but previous experience with other games has shown a distinct lack of atmosphere in supposedly fast combats. Keep combat fluid and verbal, fast and confusing. These are fast, and should be played that way. When you encounter something not in the rules - make it up! After all, that's just what I did in designing the game. The character design rules in particular are brief and to the point. Again this is for speed of play. It is not difficult for the player (or indeed the referee) to memorize the characters' skills since each has only six, with only one value (you've either got it or you haven't).

93163.name: Winfall
93163.description:
WINFALL is for anyone who has ever dreamed about what they would do if they won the lottery. The object of the game is to do things in order of how you would actually do them in real life (if you won the lottery) and end up with the highest net worth.

Pretend you just won TEN MILLION DOLLARS what would you do first? New car? New house? Take a vacation? Then what? Invest in stocks or business? It’s time to make some decisions and see if you can build an empire. Purchase cars, homes, stocks, businesses, toys, sports teams, give money to family members and take holidays. There are 3 prices for each product, you decide how much you want to invest and at the end of the game each category has a new value. The game ends whenever you like or when one player runs out of money. Each player then adds up the total amount spent in each category and the player with the highest net worth wins.

93164.description:
Spline is a very simple game for 2 players that can be played with a Shibumi set. It uses a n×n set of stacking spheres in 2 colors (4×4 or 5×5 are recommended, but larger sets can be used).

A 4×4 set, for example, is a pyramid of 30 marbles:


4×4=16 on the first layer
3×3=9 on the second layer
2×2=4 on the third layer
1×1=1 on the fourth layer


The board (n×n) starts empty.

Starting with white, each player places a marble on an empty space or platform (2×2 arrangement of marbles).

The first player making a full line of his color on any layer wins. Lines may be diagonal.

This is, for a 4×4 set, a 4-in-a-row on the first layer, or a 3-in-a-row on the 2nd layer, or a 2-in-a-row on the 3rd layer.

SPLine was born when researching on stacking spheres. It is intended to be the simplest game that can be defined for this set of components.

HAIKU for SPLINE (Cameron Browne):

Reach to touch the sky,
but heaven smiles on those who
reach from side to side.

ONLINE PLAY

http://www.jocly.com/jocly/hubquick/shibumi-spline

(human vs human and human vs computer)

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-a...

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf
93164.name: Spline

93165.name: Darwin's World: Survivor's Handbook (Savage Worlds Edition)
93165.description:
Publisher blurb:

Darwin's World is a role-playing game set in the wild, inhospitable world of mankind's ruin, after a series of devastating wars that brought the human race to the brink of extinction. In a world where radiation has altered the very course of nature, mankind has ceased to exist in its current form. Mutations and genetic variations are the edge separating a species from life and death.

The premier d20/OGL post-apocalyptic roleplaying game now for the Savage Worlds System!

93166.name: GenCon
93166.description:
From "The Score":

The Worst Four Days in Gaming
Maybe you go to GenCon to get lost in deviant fantasies. Maybe you go to GenCon to be the very first person to get the Hot New Game. Or maybe you go to kill the pain of your mundane and boring life by spending way too much money on games that no one will play with you.

Whatever your reason for going, let’s face it. It’s four days and three nights, no sleep, lots of caffeine, and more booze. Combine that with 30,000 nerds with poor social skills and easily-provoked nerd rage, and GenCon is just a fiasco waiting to happen.

From author description:

After I recovered from the sleep deprivation and mild insanity that always results from attending GenCon, it occured to me that GenCon would make a perfect playset. Think about it, tons of nerds with no sleep, lots of booze and/or caffeine, and easily-provoked nerd rage are just a fiasco waiting to happen. So here for your Fiasco enjoyment is GenCon: The Worst Four Days In Gaming.

rpgitemversion: Zeeks: psionika w roku 2088. Softcover Version
93167.name: Zeeks: Psionics in 2088
93167.description:
Publisher blurb:

WANNA PLAY SOME MIND GAMES?
When Hernando Vasquez walked into the North American Coalition embassy in Madrid and torched everything just by glaring at it, everybody knew: zeeks are among us. Some people hate 'em; some people love 'em. And make no mistake about it, tomo, that means most people either want to shoot them or use them to their own ends. But then I suppose that just makes life more interesting, ne?

HAVE YOU GOT WHAT IT TAKES?
Zeeks: Psionics In 2088 gives you an opportunity to explore the subculture of zeeks, either as a GM wanting to incorporate them into your game or a player wishing to play a psychic character. Whether you want to have a full-blown campaign focusing on the tumultuous world of psions, or just know what might be lurking back there in the shadows, we've got your back -everything from the Psi-Hunters who stalk zeeks to the fringe cults that worship them.

IN THIS BOOK YOU'LL FIND:


Loads of information about psions and how they fit into the world of Interface Zero.
Rules for creating psionic characters for Interface Zero, including new Edges, Hindrances and Powers.
A new system for Savage Psionics, without the Power Points - and still Fast, Furious and Fun!
More occupations for your characters, as well as new goodies from Malmart.
Two complete Savage Tales and a half-dozen plot hooks to help bring zeeks into your game.
Stats for new NPC friends and enemies, as well as stats for a few... other things.


This is an expansion for Savage Worlds Interface Zero (Savage Worlds), and not a stand-alone setting.

93168.name: Island of Dreams
93168.description:
Publisher blurb:

It would be an idyllic tropical island if it weren't smack in the middle of the World War II Pacific Theater. It might even still be nice if you weren't trying to take it from the Japanese.

If the horrors of war were not enough, it seems the tranquil paradise may have been housing a horror of its own, one happy to have you and the Japanese as guests. How long can you survive the hospitality?

Island of Dreams is a 37-page journey into tropical madness from Darryl Nichols for Savage Worlds' Weird War Two. , including Figure Flats from Jordan Peacock for all the personnel - and other things - present in the scenario.

93170.name: Mushroom Age
93170.description:
Join a search for true love in Mushroom Age, a unique hidden object adventure! Help Vera track down her lost love through thrilling epochs of earth's past and future! Vera's fiance, Tom, has gone missing a few days before the wedding. So she embarks on a race against time and through history to find him and save the world from futuristic evil powers that want to change history and destroy the world. Solve interesting puzzles and play mesmerizing mini-games with pre-historic characters like a dinosaur and a caveman, historic personages like Socrates and Nostradamus, robots and bad guys from the future, not to mention characters not bound by the confines of time! Featuring eye-popping puzzles and brain-bending mini-games, Mushroom Age is a wild adventure for the whole family.

Source: The Publisher Website.

93171.name: Master of Orion
93171.description:
From 1km1kt entry:

Master of Orion is a game of interstellar intrigue and combat. Players will contend against the conquering Antarans, ravaging Harvesters and vicious space monsters for fame and fortune — and sometimes for their very survival! The Master of Orion rpg includes material from all three Master of Orion games.

93172.name: Byron Falls
93172.description:
Publisher Blurb:
In the small town of Byron Falls, Minnesota, there’s more going on than most suspect. Witches and warlocks, vampires and werewolves, mummies and ghosts haunt every corner. And, of course, brilliant, beautiful young girls who want desperately to fall in love with them.

Byron Falls is the second Little Game from John Wick's forthcoming Big Book of Little Games. Players take the roles of lonely, beautiful and misunderstood high school girls who meet and fall in love with lonely, beautiful and misunderstood monsters.

Instead of stats like "strength" or "dexterity," players roll dice for their relationships, building life-long friendships and bitter rivalries while trying to romance the moody vampire in study hall.

Welcome to Byron Falls.

Don't you dare fall in love.

93174.name: Dungeon Party
93174.description:
From Introduction:

Dungeon Party RPG is a solo roleplaying game representing a diverse party of fantastic adventurers delving into dangerous dungeons wherein horrible monsters and magical treasures await, all in a far off world of fantasy…

In Dungeon Party RPG, a single player takes the role of a party of dungeon explorers. Instead of playing a single character, the entire party of characters is the role played by the player. Instead of characteristics, the characters within the party represent the only factors that define it, and no characters are individualized or have characteristics themselves. In a way, the dungeon party is the “player character” and the characters in the party are it’s “characteristics”.

93175.name: Frenzy
93175.description:
Frenzy was an arcade game published by Stern Electronics in 1982. It was a sequel to the hit 1980 arcade game Berserk.

Frenzy followed the basic paradigm set by Berserk: you are in a maze full of hostile robots who are shooting at you. The goal of the game is survive as long as possible and score points by killing robots and travelling from room to room. The game has no end other than the player losing all of his or her lives.

You have a gun, so you can shoot back, and the robots are fortunately not that bright, and can often be tricked into shooting each other. If you linger too long in a room, however, a bouncing smiley face, "Evil Otto", appears, and relentlessly chases you. Evil Otto will happily destroy any robots in his way, and can move through walls.

Source: Wikipedia, "Frenzy (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93176.name: Battle of Gundabad
93176.description:
Battle of Gundabad is a DECK BUILDING CARD game. Every player plays with his own set of cards. At game end the player with the most victory point (VP) wins!

The game consists of 27 cards with thousands of combinations and 2 game modes: Campaign and Normal Modes. In Campaign Mode you help Bolg to save his father and all others unexpected challenges, while in Normal Mode every game you will be randomly assigned 10 out of 20 action cards which consists thousands of different combinations. Battle of Gundabad is a welcome addition to any deck building gamer's collection!

The story: Once apon a time in the Orcs dominion Azog was a respectful chieftain at Mount Gundabad. His son Bolg, despite the talent and strength he possessed, cared about nothing but playing with friends. Until one morning Bolg found that Azog was kidnapped by Rodlin the Hammer-Fist. Bolg had to make his own way to save his father. A journey with challenges, betrayal and crisis lie in front of Bolg. Can you help him?

Source: The Developer Website.

This application is an unauthorized Dominion clone for the iPhone.

93177.name: Abaddon
93177.description:
Finally, a quality dual-stick shooter with multiplayer over XBox Live! Join your friends as you defend Abaddon in three intense game modes. You will be able to choose from a unique selection of upgradeable ships and weapons, as well as 7 powerful abilities. You can choose to defeat the enemy with your own piloting skills, or you can upgrade Abaddon's turrets and clean up the mess after they lay havoc on your foe.

Source: The Game Website.

93178.name: Abronium Party
93178.description:
You’ll find yourself in an artistic cyberspace world controlling a glowing entity through multiple different gamemodes. Play soccer, fetch, capture the flag, race or chase with or against friends and family. You can choose to play campaign, co-op campaign or tournament. In party mode you can play with up to 16 players on a single xbox. By automatically using computer replacements people can join and leave the game as they come and go, without disrupting the ongoing tournament. Team up or play head to head while listening to an awesome soundtrack!

Source: The Developer Website.

93179.name: Roc 'N Rope
93179.description:
From Wikipedia:

Roc 'N Rope is a 1983 arcade game developed by Kosuka and published by Konami. The player, impersonating a "flashlight and harpoon gun" equipped archaeologist had to ascend a series of rocky platforms in a Lost World scenario to reach a Phoenix bird, the object of his quest. Along the way he had to avoid ferocious man-sized dinosaurs and belligerent red-haired cavemen against whom he had no direct means of offense. The only ways to defeat the opponents were either temporary (dazing them with the flashlight) or indirect (waiting for them to be suspended on a harpoon rope to make them fall down), and element which added a certain amount of trickiness to the game, unusual for its time. Bonus to collect along the way included fallen phoenix feathers and phoenix eggs, which granted the player invulnerability from the prehistoric denizens for a short period of time.

Source: Wikipedia, "Roc 'N Rope", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93181.name: Gun Metal
93181.description:
Gun Metal is a 3-D shooting game, released in 2002, for the Xbox and PC by the now defunct Rage Software Limited. The lead artist Nick Tipping and lead programmer Mark Featherstone on Gun Metal went on to form Moonpod.

Gun Metal allows players to pilot a futuristic mech which can transform into a plane. The game is based around a war (sometime in the future) on a planet called Helios, where humans have settled. Enemy spacecraft have followed them from Earth and are attempting to exterminate the colony. Project Gunmetal is a massive operation which oversaw the creation of a supremely powerful war machine. In its primary form, a walking "humanoid" mech many dozens of feet high, it possesses a range of 12 weapons and an electronic shield. At the push of a button, it transforms into an advanced fighter jet reminiscent of a modern fighter jet. It also possesses 12 weapons, ranging from napalm, pulse cannons, harpoons and rockets.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gun Metal (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93182.name: Signs & Portents (Issue 87 - Dec 2010)
rpgissuearticle: A Call to Arms: Noble Armada
Lone Wolf 29: Timeline and The Story So Far
Taking the Law to the Lawless
93182.description:
Publisher blurb (from publisher's website):
In this month's issue;

A Call to Arms: Noble Armada
Looking deeper into the forthcoming miniatures game, peering at the mysteries of the new critical hits system, stealthships and boarding, as well as some of the new ships on the way.

Lone Wolf
Mr Dever unveils some of his plans for the all new 29th book of the series.

Clockwork & Chivalry
New professions for the criminal mind, including Highwayman and Ruffian.

Traveller
A bumper Christmas treat for Traveller fans - the complete Death Station classic adventure, fully updated for the latest edition of rules!

Chthonian Stars
A new preview of this Traveller setting, now set for release early next year. This time, we take a peek at one of the nasty beasties of Chthonian Stars, as well as some of its gorgeous artwork.

RuneQuest
A selection of mighty books for the magically inclined.

Corporation
Looking at Archons and, more importantly for agents, their technology.

Traveller
Every character in Traveller has a backstory - use these old flames to really spice up the meetings of long term friends.

Judge Dredd
Explore the lawless region of the Cursed Earth as a Township Judge, or while taking the Long Walk.

93183.name: Inherit the Earth: Quest for the Orb
93183.description:
Inherit the Earth: Quest for the Orb (ITE) is a computer game, developed by The Dreamers Guild and published by Jon Van Caneghem through New World Computing.

The adventure featured a world full of talking, humanoid animals, amongst them a fox on his quest to find a stolen orb, a relic of the mythical humans.

In a far future, mankind is extinct and Earth is populated by several tribes of speaking, human-like animals, living in a medieval world.

The game begins with the protagonist, Rif of the Fox Tribe, being falsely accused of having stolen the Orb of Storms (a technological relic of humankind which is able to predict and control the weather). In order to prove his innocence and free his girlfriend Rhene, who is being held hostage by the Boar King, Rif is determined to find the real thief of the Orb.

Source: Wikipedia, "Inherit the Earth: Quest for the Orb", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93184.name: Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Templar
93184.description:
From publisher blurb:

DMs, do you need a way to keep your monsters fresh and interesting without dropping a wad of cash on a new monster book? Then let Blackdirge Publishing lend you a hand with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates. Each installment of Blackdirge's Bargain Templates features a new monster template and two example monsters that can be dropped right into your 4E campaign. Each Blackdirge's Bargain Templates is only 99 cents, but is fully illustrated and designed with the same skill and innovation you've come to expect from Blackdirge Publishing.

The latest Blackdirge's Bargain Templates adds some good ol' fashioned fanatical devotion to your monsters. The Templar template allows your humanoid monsters to enforce the will of their gods by channeling divine energy. Templars use this divine energy to smite enemies, heal allies, and imbue their weapons with searing radiant power or withering necrotic death. So bring the power and the glory back to your religious zealots with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Templar.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Templar features the following all new 4E material:

The Templar Template
Example Monster #1: Blackfire Slayer (Dragonborn Templar)
Example Monster #2: Azer Templar (Azer Templar)

93185.description: In Tetris Link, based on the popular video game Tetris, players take turns dropping tetromino blocks into a grid, attempting to link same-colored tetrominos to score while simultaneously blocking opponents from doing the same. Players score points by linking three or more tetrominos together, but they lose points if they leave empty spaces in the tower grid. Once the tower is full, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.
93185.name: Tetris Link

93186.name: Dino-Deal
93186.description:
Four dinosaur cards are openly placed in the middle of the table. Each player now secretly bids on one of them. If s/he is the only one bidding on a particular dinosaur, s/he gets it. If several players are after the same dinosaur, the owner is decided by die rolls.
The player with the most valuable dinosaur collection at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

93187.name: Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Trollborn
93187.description:
From publisher blurb:

DMs, do you need a way to keep your monsters fresh and interesting without dropping a wad of cash on a new monster book? Then let Blackdirge Publishing lend you a hand with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates. Each installment of Blackdirge's Bargain Templates features a new monster template and two example monsters that can be dropped right into your 4E campaign. Each Blackdirge's Bargain Templates is only 99 cents, but is fully illustrated and designed with the same skill and innovation you've come to expect from Blackdirge Publishing.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates kicks off with the Trollborn, a template that allows you to created monstrous troll hybrids from beasts, humanoids, and magical beasts. Also featured are two example monsters created with the trollborn template, including Ig'Yok, a horrific trollborn hezrou that has established its own trollish kingdom in the heart of a dismal swamp.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Trollborn features the following all new 4E material:

The Trollborn Template
Example Monster #1: Troll Hounds (Trollborn Dire Wolves)
Example Monster #1: Ig'Yok (Trollborn Hezrou)

93188.name: Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Venomous
93188.description:
From publisher blurb:

DMs, do you need a way to keep your monsters fresh and interesting without dropping a wad of cash on a new monster book? Then let Blackdirge Publishing lend you a hand with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates. Each installment of Blackdirge's Bargain Templates features a new monster template and two example monsters that can be dropped right into your 4E campaign. Each Blackdirge's Bargain Templates is only 99 cents, but is fully illustrated and designed with the same skill and innovation you've come to expect from Blackdirge Publishing.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Venomous is sure to add a bit more bite to your monsters. Venomous creatures can spew blinding poison, coat weapons with poisonous spittle, and inject venom deep into an enemies flesh with puncturing fangs and envenomed claws. So turn your beasts, humanoids, and magical beasts into poisonous paragons with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Venomous.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Venomous features the following new 4E material:

The Venomous Template
Example Monster #1: Blightscale Lancer (Venomous Lizardfolk)
Example Monster #2: Scourgewing Vrock (Venomous Vrock)

93189.name: Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Brutish
93189.description:
From publisher blurb:

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates continues with Brutish, a template that turns even the wimpiest humanoid into a powerhouse of destructive might. Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Brutish also features two example monsters created with the brutish template, including Karvok Gatesmasher, an enterprising ogre who has turned his penchant for breaking things into a lucrative mercenary career. So add a bit more brawn to your humanoids with Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Brutish.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Brutish features the following all new 4E material:

The Brutish Template
Example Monster #1: Gnoll Manslayer (Brutish Gnoll Marauder)
Example Monster #1: Karvok Gatesmasher (Brutish Ogre Warhulk)

93190.name: Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Abominable
93190.description:
From publisher blurb:

With Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Abominable you can transform your humanoid monsters into the infamous "abominable snowmen" of fable and legend. In addition, this template can turn your beasts and magical beasts into cold-blooded horrors sure to make the frozen wastes and tundra of your campaign world all the more perilous.

Blackdirge's Bargain Templates: Abominable features the following all new 4E material:

The Abominable Template
Example Monster #1: Blizzard Worg (Abominable Worg)
Example Monster #2: Frosthorn Minotaur (Abominable Savage Minotaur)

93192.description:
The game board depicts a cherry pie. On the pie there are flies which are attached to strings held by the players. Each flie is different; wearing different items of clothing. The active player holds a fly swatter and rolls a die (d12). The players whose flies show an item of clothing that was rolled have to pull that fly's string instantly while the active player is trying to swat the fly. A player who was too slow or pulled the wrong string has to give the active player a pie chip. The player with most chips at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)
93192.name: Flinke Fliegen

boardgamehonor: 2012 Golden Geek Best Board Game Expansion Nominee
2012 Golden Geek Best Board Game Expansion Winner
93193.description:
Alien Frontiers: Factions adds a number of items to the Alien Frontiers base game:


Ship and colony tokens for a fifth player.
Factions (thus the name), with each faction providing its owner a special ability and new orbital facilities under his control.
Agendas, which are hidden objectives that allow a player to earn bonus points at game's end or when the agenda is revealed in-game.
New Alien Tech cards, such as the Lunar Tunneler, which will allow its owner to pay one fuel to receive an extra ore when using the Lunar Mine. This card's discard power will send all ships docked at the Lunar Mine to the Maintenance Bay, which can be useful when the Mine is clogged with high-value ships.
93193.name: Alien Frontiers: Factions
boardgamepodcastepisode: OBG 113: Hey New Guy

boardgamehonor: 2011 Lucca Games Best Publishing Project Winner
93194.description:
It’s year “011” in an alternative 19th century. The Inscrutable Organ of Eternity is hidden somewhere in Turin, and it’s the only instrument that can prevent the coming Ragnarök. Only one of the 8 Characters in the game is the “Chosen One” who can play the Organ. One of the others, meanwhile, has been possessed by the Spirit of Fenrir the Wolf, and will try to prevent the Chosen One from reaching the Organ.

The goal of the game, is to identify and deliver the Chosen One and the song of Making (which is composed as part of the game play) to the Inscrutable Organ of Eternity before the 12th hour.

011 is played over 11 rounds, called Hours. Each Hour is divided into 5 phases. All players, in order, must complete one phase, before the next phase begins:
1. Reveal Event
2. Bid for Turn Order
3. Place Clues on the Map
4. Character Actions and Movement
5. Play Location Tiles

Once all 5 Phases are complete, advance the Hour Hand one space on the Ragnarök Clock. If the Hand reaches XII (and so, the 11th Hour has passed), the game ends and all players lose! Otherwise, a new Round begins with Phase 1.

93195.name: Metal Gear Solid (GBC)
93195.description:
Metal Gear Solid, released as Metal Gear: Ghost Babel​ (メタルギア ゴーストバベル, Metaru Gia Gōsuto Baberu) in Japan and Asia, is a 2000 stealth action game produced by Konami for the Game Boy Color. Based on the 1998 PlayStation game of the same title, the Game Boy Color version of Metal Gear Solid (or Ghost Babel) is not a conversion of the previous game, but an original game produced specifically for the portable platform. The story of Ghost Babel is not set in the same continuity as the original Metal Gear Solid, but instead serves as an alternate sequel to the events of the original Metal Gear, set seven years after Solid Snake's mission in Outer Heaven.

Source: Wikipedia, "Metal Gear Solid (Game Boy)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

93196.description:
In Der Kletter-Retter, the "game board" is a tower. On top of it there is a princess held captive by an evil sorcerer. The sorcerer and a valiant knight are hanging from the towers with ropes. 24 key tokens are spread out around the tower.

One player now flips open a keyhole card and turns a sand timer. All players are now trying to grab a matching key. When all players hold one, the keys are compared with the keyhole. If a key matches, the knight climbs up one storey. If none matches, the sorcerer climbs up. On certain levels there are guards, which means that the knight has to roll a die to advance (if he's failing it, the sorcerer advances. If the knight gets to the top first, all players win.

(User summary by HilkMAN)
93196.name: Der Kletter-Retter

93197.name: Gunbird Special Edition
93197.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Gunbird Special Edition", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Gunbird Special Edition, or Gunbird 1&2 is a compilation that includes arcade versions of Gunbird and Gunbird 2.

New features include 8 difficulty settings, and adjustable view option (letter boxed and vertical, full screen and horizontal), Practice Mode.

93198.name: Dungeon Magic
93198.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Dungeon Magic", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Dungeon Magic, known in Japan as Lightbringer (ライトブリンガー), is a 1994 arcade game by Taito Corporation Japan and it also included on Taito Legends 2. Unlike most medieval/fantasy beat 'em ups it featured an isometric viewing angle, some platforming (usually involving players stacking rocks or crates to climb on and jump to treasure chests), unusually large stylised sprites, and variable blood/gore settings.

In this game, up to four players can choose four characters in four different occupations: a knight, a brawler, an archer and a wizard. Collecting treasure gave the characters experience points, and levelling up shortened the time it took a character to charge his/her super attack (by holding the attack button).

In addition to treasure, items included food (which restored health) elemental upgrades to weapons (which made them stronger against specific opponents) various single-use thrown weapons (and a five-shot crossbow), shields that would automatically block enemy attacks for a short time, and refills for a player's "magic" (basically a desperation move). Often, instead of items or treasure, a chest/barrel/etc. would contain a trap like "freezing smoke", poison gas, lightning, or even traps that temporarily transformed the player into small animals who could move but not attack.

The enemies in the game were fairly standard for fantasy arcade games, including orcs, slimes, lizardmen, werewolves, carnivorous plants, harpies, and others. Bosses included demons, giant snakes, spider-women, and more. The game also featured numerous branching paths that presented different rooms, secret areas, and even different bosses, and had to be played through multiple times to see all of the rooms available.

93199.description:
How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party.

All stories in this edition stem from literature: detectives, thrillers and horror.
93199.name: Black Stories Krimi Edition

93200.name: Bible Checkers
93200.description:
"A new way to play checkers and learn about the 'fruits of the spirit'"

Bible Checkers is a Christian-themed game of checkers with a few variant rules -- red squares are interspersed in an otherwise black/white board, no pieces are ever removed from play, and players attempt to reach the opposite side of the board's "Fruit of the Spirit" squares ("Love," "Goodness," "Joy," "Faith," "Long-Suffering," etc.)

93201.name: ZeFRS Core Rules
93201.description:
From the Introduction
Welcome to ZeFRS (Zeb’s Fantasy Roleplaying System), a complete rules set for gritty, cinematic, swashbuckling swords-and-sorcery role playing games. You won’t find pansy elves, drunken dwarves, or cutesy halflings or gnomes in these rules.
